blocks.value: Saint Alphonsa of the Immaculate Conception was born in Kerala, India in 1910. She is the first woman of Indian origin to be canonized as a saint by the Catholic Church.

From childhood, Alphonsa experienced tremendous sufferingâ€”illness, burns, and chronic pain. To avoid an arranged marriage, she accidentally stepped into a pit of burning chaff, suffering severe burns. She joined the Franciscan Clarist Congregation, offering her sufferings for souls.

Despite constant physical agony, Alphonsa remained joyful and devoted to God. She said, 'I will remain on the cross with a smiling face.' She died in 1946 at age 36 and was canonized in 2008. She is invoked for healing and strength in suffering.
